When multiple policy transactions are started and based on the same policy period, it may create a preemption situation. The first job that finishes preempts all other jobs, as the jobs that try to complete later do not have the changes made by the job that finishes first. We will walk through an example with a policy of your choice. From the policy file, Start a Policy Change. Go to PA Coverages. Change the Comprehensive Deductible from 1000 to 250. Click Save Draft to save the changes. Do not issue this policy change job, but go back to the same policy file. Start another policy change. Start another policy change. This warning does not indicate that a preemption will necessarily occur, or that it already occurred. Go to PA Coverages. Change the Comprehensive Deductible from 1000 to 500 this time. We will finish this policy change. Click Quote. Issue the policy change. Since this job finishes first, it preempts the other open policy change job. It offers a link to go to the unfinished policy job created earlier. The preemption warning message and the handle preemption button appear on every page of the open policy change. Go to Policy Review. Expand the tree structure on the Differences tab, which compares the current policy change job with the existing policy data that it is based on. As you can see, it displays the existing policy's comprehensive deductible as 1000, which is prior to the other issued policy change, so it is not based on the most up-to-date policy data. You must handle the preemption before you can continue the policy change process. On the Handle Preemptions page, it compares the existing policy that the current job is based on with the other policy change job that has completed earlier. Expand the tree structure. Review the data. There are several options here. The Apply All Changes button allows you to apply changes from the job that finishes first. The Withdraw button discards the current job. The Decide Later button saves the draft and returns to the Policy Review screen. Let's click Apply All Changes. It goes back to the Differences tab on Policy Review, which compares the data to the policy review. The Preemptions tab pairs the current policy change job with the existing policy data that it is based on. Expand the tree structure. After applying all changes, the existing policy has been updated to the most recent data. This is the end of the demonstration of preemption. A renewal transaction is automatically started by a batch job, for policies expiring in a number of days defined in PolicyCenter. However, a user can manually start a renewal at any time. Go to a policy file that is in force. To manually start a renewal, click Actions. Select Renew Policy. Click OK to confirm. The renewal job is in the renewal workflow. It will become automatically quoted and it will be completed on the renewal start date. Or you can click Next. Before the renewal is bound, changes may be made. Make the policy editable. This applies to renewal jobs started by the batch job as well. It removes the renewal from the workflow and puts it in a draft status. After making the desired changes, quote the renewal job. There are two bind options. Renew puts the job back in the renewal workflow. It will be completed on the renewal start date and ends up bound and renewed. You can still edit the renewal job if you want. Issue now binds and issues the renewal immediately as a new policy term. The renewal job is completed and cannot be edited. Let's select Renew. Select a renewal code. Select a renewal code. Save the data. The renewal job is in the workflow and has a status of Renewing. Click on the renewal job to return to it. This time, we decide to issue the renewal immediately. Click Edit Policy Transaction again to put it in the draft status. Click Quote. Click Bind Options. This time, select Issue Now because we do not want to make any changes. The renewal job is bound as a new policy term. Go to the Account. The new policy term is scheduled because the current term has not expired. When the date reaches the start date of the renewal term, the new term becomes in force and the previous term becomes expired. This is the end of demonstration for manual renewal.

The cancellation transaction is the process of voiding a policy while it is in force. In this demo, you will see the process of a policy cancellation. In this example, Alice Applegate has to log in to cancel a policy. Alice has to cancel Ray Newton's policy today because he has not paid his premium. To cancel the policy, Alice initiates a cancellation transaction through the Actions menu. Select Cancel Policy. After the cancellation wizard starts, Alice selects Insurer as the source of the cancellation. This is because Ray has not paid his premium and the insurer must cancel the policy as a result. In the dropdown titled, Reason, Alice selects Non-Payment. Alice includes details about the reason in the text field. Since Ray did not pay, she writes the details. Alice starts the cancellation transaction when she selects Bind. Alice selects Schedule Cancellation. Alice has successfully scheduled the cancellation. Alice is working with another policy that Ray has in cancellation. She wants to rescind the cancellation. She starts with the Actions menu. Alice selects Rescind Cancellation and selects the cancellation. Now Alice clicks the Close Options dropdown. Alice clicks on Policy Transactions and selects Recent Cancellation. To view the transaction, she clicks on the Policy link. Alice clicks on Policy Transactions. The transaction list reflects the current status of the cancellation transaction. This is the end of the demonstration.

A transaction or job is out of sequence if its effective date is earlier than other bound transactions on the policy for that contractual term. In this example, a customer calls to change a car's color in an auto policy, effective on March 1st. Later, the customer calls to make some changes effective on February 1st. Click Actions. Create the first policy change. Set the effective date of the policy change to March 1st, using the calendar. Click Next to start the policy change process. Go to Vehicles. Change the car's color to yellow. Go to PIA Coverages. Medical limit is changed to 10,000. Quote the policy change. Issue the policy. Go back to the same policy file. The customer calls again to say that he had the car painted blue. And added a new driver on February 1st. Start the second policy change job. Set the effective date to February 1st, which is earlier than the previous policy change job. Click Next to start the process. Click OK to proceed. The out of sequence message is displayed on the top of every page. Go to Drivers. Add a new driver. Create a new driver. Simply select an existing driver. Click the Roles tab. Make sure to populate the fields for year first licensed and the number of accidents and violations. Go to Vehicles. Change the vehicle's color to blue. Go to PIA Coverages. The customer also wants to select a higher medical limit. Select 20,000. Try to quote.  An error message is displayed for an out of sequence conflict that requires resolution. Go to Policy Review. Click Change Conflicts. The conflicts occur when changes are made to the same fields. In this example, the color and medical limit. The newly added driver does not cause any conflict because the change is not on the same field. You can click the Override All or Override None buttons. You can also resolve individual conflict by selecting Yes or No in the Override Future Conflicts column. In this example, click No for the car's color, so that the color is not on the same field. The color blue of the current job is only effective from February 1st to March 1st. On March 1st, the color yellow from the other job will be effective for the policy, while the liability limit will be merged forward to the job with a later effective date. Click Submit. After submitting the resolution, it cannot be reverted. Click OK to confirm. Now you can quote the policy change. Issue the policy. This is the end of demonstration of out of sequence transaction.
